Body:
I'm sending sensor data using Arduino and ESP8266. But while compiling the sketch in Arduino I'm getting an error saying - deprecated conversion from string constant to 'char*' [-Wwrite-strings].

#include SoftwareSerial.h"	SoftwareSerial esp(10
column10: TX void setup() { esp.begin(9600); Serial.begin(9600); delay(100); Serial.println("Started..."); reset(); connectWifi(); } //reset the esp8266 module void reset() { esp.println("AT+RST"); delay(1000); if (esp.find("OK")) Serial.println("Module Reset"); //error } "

Body: There are two string constants" on that line
column9: please put the body of the `if` statement on a separate line and it will be easier to know which of the two the compiler means."

Body: Also, what is `esp`? What is `esp.find()`? Not knowing Arduino programming that well, is it a standard object? Something you declared yourself?
esp os softwareserial / predefined object. i did not declared esp.
where is two string constants . im not getting two string constants. can u edit it @JoachimPileborg
By string constant" I assume the compiler means the string literals
column9: and on the offending line you have `"OK"` and `"Module Reset"`."

Body: According to [this `SoftwareSerial` reference](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Reference/SoftwareSerial) there is no `find` member function?
just add a cast (char *) before your string. Not the best way, but it works, and in arduino it's not so bad.
then how to check check if value is ok or not ? in esp.. im new in iot and esp8266. how to cast can u plz edit that line .@Aeldred

As Aeldred said you have just to cast you String to char*.

so your sketch will looks like :

#include SoftwareSerial.h"	SoftwareSerial esp(10
column10: TX void setup() { esp.begin(9600); Serial.begin(9600); delay(100); Serial.println("Started..."); reset(); connectWifi(); } //reset the esp8266 module void reset() { esp.println("AT+RST"); delay(1000); if (esp.find((char*)"OK")) Serial.println("Module Reset"); //error } "
